speaker: Citizens
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Before a gate of the city.

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS, VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, MENENIUS, COMINIUS, with the young Nobility of Rome

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Where is your ancient courage? you were used

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To say extremity was the trier of spirits;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That common chances common men could bear;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That when the sea was calm all boats alike

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A noble cunning: you were used to load me

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With precepts that would make invincible

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The heart that conn'd them.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: O heavens! O heavens!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Nay! prithee, woman,--

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And occupations perish!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What, what, what!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If you had been the wife of Hercules,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thy tears are salter than a younger man's,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And venomous to thine eyes. My sometime general,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have seen thee stem, and thou hast oft beheld

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: 'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As 'tis to laugh at 'em. My mother, you wot well

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My hazards still have been your solace: and

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Believe't not lightly--though I go alone,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen--your son

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Will or exceed the common or be caught

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With cautelous baits and practise.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: My first son.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: With thee awhile: determine on some course,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: More than a wild exposture to each chance

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That starts i' the way before thee.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O the gods!

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And we of thee: so if the time thrust forth

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: O'er the vast world to seek a single man,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And lose advantage, which doth ever cool

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I' the absence of the needer.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Fare ye well:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My friends of noble touch, when I am forth,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: While I remain above the ground, you shall

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hear from me still, and never of me aught

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: But what is like me formerly.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That's worthily

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: If I could shake off but one seven years

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'ld with thee every foot.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Give me thy hand: Come.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Exeunt
